label: Letter from Fong Lee Wong to Laura M. Bragg, July 16, 1929
description: In this four page handwritten letter, Fong Lee Wong writes about ROTC camp, marksmanship medals, summer travel plans with Mr. Li and Mr. Wang, and his bill from the Charleston Library Society.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: In this four page handwritten letter, Fong Lee Wong writes about ROTC camp, marksmanship medals, summer travel plans with Mr. Li and Mr. Wang, and his bill from the Charleston Library Society.

metadata.label: Access Statement
metadata.value: For more information contact The Citadel Archives and Museum at Daniel Library, The Citadel, 171 Moultrie Street, Charleston, SC 29409

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 600 dpi, 24-bit depth, color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Plattsburg, N.Y.
July 16, 1929

Dear Miss Bragg,

	By this time you may, I think, have received my last letter. Colonel heard from Chhia Mei a few days ago, tellling him that you had been at Washington. If you did not stay very long at Richmond, you may have received my last letter at home. 

	Now we have only five more days in camp. But these five more days will not be so nice as all the days we have enjoyed here in Plattsburg for to--morrow we are going to Maneovur[sic Maneuver]Camp whick gives the real soldier's life. Although it [2] will not be so nice, as I just said, it is really what we want.

	This afternoon all medels [sic medals] were given to those who were qualified either in rifle or pistol and or both. I received two medels, [sic medals] one for rifle and one for pistol. The one for pistol costs me five dollars. You may wonder the reason why? Well, before we had pistol range, Sergeant and I had a bet. I told him that I would be able to get qualified in pistol range, if I would I would give him five dollars. On the other hand if I should fail, as I expected, in pistol range, he should give me five dollars. He accepted this bet. When coming to fire for record in pistol, I did not know the reason why I got qualified. So I had to give Sergeant five dollars and I did. It was for this reason that, as I said, my pistol medel [sic] "costs me five dollars."

	As soon as the camp is over I shall go to Meadville, Pennsylvania, to visit my German teacher Miss Schafheitlin. She wrote to  me, asking me to visit her and stay with her for a few days. But Mr. Li is expecting me at Columbus, Ohio, all the time, so I shall not be able to stay at Meadville more than two days.

	The rest of my summer will be spent at Columbus with both Mr. Li and Mr. Wang. I will write to you as soon as I get there.

	This afternoon on receiving a notice from Charleston Library Society, asking me to pay the arear [sic arrears] for my membership. I sent a money order. I hope I can be a full member when I come back to Charleston this fall.

	Yours affectionately,
	
	Fong Lee Wong

[From:]Fong Lee Wong
c/o Chinese Educational Mission
2645 Conn. Ave., N.W.
Washington, D.C.

[Addressed:] Miss Laura M. Bragg
38 Chalmers Street
Charleston, S.C.
Valentine Museum
Richmond, Va

[Postmark:] Plattsburgh, N.Y. Military Br
Jul 18
2 PM
